\section{Description}
\label{description::doc}\label{description:description}
This is a set of packages and scripts that provides a simple way for programmatically interfacing with Tanium's SOAP API. It is comprised of four parts:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Tanium Server SOAP API: The SOAP server embedded into the Tanium server itself, listens on port 444 but is also available via port 443.

\item {} 
TaniumPy Python Package ({\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}}): A python package comprised of a set of python objects automatically generated from the WSDL file that describes the Tanium SOAP API. These python objects handle the serialization and deserialization of XML to and from the Tanium Server SOAP API. Located in \code{lib/taniumpy}

\item {} 
PyTan Python Package: ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}): A python package that provides a set of methods to make interfacing with TaniumPy more human friendly. Located in \code{lib/pytan}

\item {} 
PyTan Command Line Scripts: A set of command line scripts that utilize the PyTan Package ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}) to make it easy for non-programmers to create/get/delete/ask/deploy objects via the Tanium Server SOAP API.

\end{itemize}


\section{Why it was created}
\label{description:why-it-was-created}
This was created to solve for the following needs:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Create a python package ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}) to provide a set of methods for making it easier to programmatically interface with Tanium via the SOAP API.

\item {} 
Create a set of command line scripts utilizing the {\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}} package that handle the argument parsing, thereby providing non-programmers with command line access to the functionality therein.

\item {} 
Provide a way to ask questions and get results via Python and/or the command line.

\item {} 
Provide a way to deploy actions and get results via Python and/or the command line.

\item {} 
Provide a way to export/import objects in JSON via Python and/or the command line.

\end{itemize}


\section{Requirements}
\label{description:requirements}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Python 2.7

\item {} 
A working install of Tanium Server 6.2

\end{itemize}


\section{Installation}
\label{description:installation}\begin{description}
\item[{Windows Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Download Python 2.7 from \href{https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/}{https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/}

\item {} 
Install Python 2.7 -- if you accept the default paths it will install to \code{C:\textbackslash{}Python27}

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\item {} 
If you did not accept the default install path for Python 2.7, edit \code{pytan\textbackslash{}winbin\textbackslash{}CONFIG.bat} to change the \emph{PYTHON} variable to point to the full path of \emph{python.exe}

\end{itemize}

\item[{OS X Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
OS X 10.8 and higher come with Python 2.7 out of the box

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\end{itemize}

\item[{Linux Installation}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Ensure Python 2.7 is installed

\item {} 
Ensure the first \emph{python} binary in your path points to your Python 2.7 installation

\item {} 
Copy PyTan from github to your local machine somewhere

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\section{Usage}
\label{description:usage}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
For command line usage, refer to Command Line Help Index

\item {} 
For API Examples, refer to the {\hyperref[examples/pytan_examples::doc]{\emph{pytan API examples}}}

\item {} 
For in depth API Documentation, refer to the {\hyperref[pytan::doc]{\emph{pytan package}}}, especially the {\hyperref[pytan.handler::doc]{\emph{pytan.handler module}}}

\end{itemize}


\section{Directory Layout}
\label{description:directory-layout}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\textbf{EXAMPLES/ directory}: contains a set of example python files that show how to use the various methods exposed by ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}})

\item {} 
\textbf{BUILD/ directory}: contains the scripts that build the HTML and PDF documentation in doc/, generate the ({\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}}), generate the python examples in EXAMPLES/, generate some of the command line scripts in bin/, and generate all of the documentation for the command line scripts in doc/\_static/bin\_doc

\item {} 
\textbf{bin/ directory}: contains all of the command line scripts that utilize the ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}})

\item {} 
\textbf{doc/ directory}: contains the HTML and PDF documentation

\item {} 
\textbf{lib/ directory}: contains the python libraries ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}}) and ({\hyperref[taniumpy:module-taniumpy]{\code{taniumpy}}}), as well as other python libraries

\item {} 
\textbf{test/ directory}: contains the unit and functional tests for ({\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}})

\item {} 
\textbf{winbin/ directory}: contains the Windows batch scripts which wrap around the python command line scripts in bin/

\end{itemize}

\subsubsection{Pytan api basic handler example}
\label{examples/pytan_api_basic_handler_example:pytan-api-basic-handler-example}\label{examples/pytan_api_basic_handler_example::doc}
Here is an example for how to instantiate a \code{pytan.Handler} object.

The username, password, host, and maybe port as well need to be provided on a per Tanium server basis.


\paragraph{Example Python Code}
\label{examples/pytan_api_basic_handler_example:example-python-code}
\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Path to lib directory which contains pytan package}
\PYG{n}{PYTAN\PYGZus{}LIB\PYGZus{}PATH} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{../lib}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} connection info for Tanium Server}
\PYG{n}{USERNAME} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Tanium User}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{PASSWORD} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{T@n!um}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{HOST} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{172.16.31.128}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{PORT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{444}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Logging conrols}
\PYG{n}{LOGLEVEL} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
\PYG{n}{DEBUGFORMAT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{False}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{sys}\PYG{o}{,} \PYG{n+nn}{tempfile}
\PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{PYTAN\PYGZus{}LIB\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{pytan}
\PYG{n}{handler} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pytan}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{Handler}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{n}{username}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{USERNAME}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{password}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{PASSWORD}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{host}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{HOST}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{port}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{PORT}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{loglevel}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{LOGLEVEL}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{debugformat}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{DEBUGFORMAT}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{handler}
\end{Verbatim}

\PYG{n}{PASSWORD} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{T@n!um}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{HOST} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{172.16.31.128}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{PORT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{444}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Logging conrols}
\PYG{n}{LOGLEVEL} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
\PYG{n}{DEBUGFORMAT} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{False}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{sys}\PYG{o}{,} \PYG{n+nn}{tempfile}
\PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{PYTAN\PYGZus{}LIB\PYGZus{}PATH}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{pytan}

\paragraph{Ask manual human question sensor with parameters and no supplied parameters}
\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_no_supplied_parameters::doc}\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_no_supplied_parameters:ask-manual-human-question-sensor-with-parameters-and-no-supplied-parameters}
Ask a manual question using human strings by referencing the name of a single sensor that takes parameters, but not supplying any parameters (and letting pytan automatically determine the appropriate default value for those parameters which require a value).

No sensor filters, sensor parameters, sensor filter options, question filters, or question options supplied.

\paragraph{Ask manual human question sensor with parameters and filter}
\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_filter:ask-manual-human-question-sensor-with-parameters-and-filter}\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_filter::doc}
Ask a manual question using human strings by referencing the name of a single sensor that takes parameters, but supplying only two of the four parameters that are used by the sensor.

Also supply a sensor filter that limits the column data that is shown to values that match the regex `.*Shared.*'.

No sensor filter options, question filters, or question options supplied.

\paragraph{Ask manual human question sensor with filter and 3 options}
\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_filter_and_3_options:ask-manual-human-question-sensor-with-filter-and-3-options}\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_filter_and_3_options::doc}
Ask a manual question using human strings by referencing the name of a single sensor.

Also supply a sensor filter that limits the column data that is shown to values that contain Windows (which is short hand for regex match against .*Windows.*).

Also supply filter options that re-fetches any cached data that is older than 3600 seconds, matches all values supplied in the filter, and ignores case for any value match of the filter.

No sensor paramaters, question filters, or question options supplied.

\paragraph{Ask manual human question sensor with parameters and filter and options}
\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_filter_and_options:ask-manual-human-question-sensor-with-parameters-and-filter-and-options}\label{examples/ask_manual_human_question_sensor_with_parameters_and_filter_and_options::doc}
Ask a manual question using human strings by referencing the name of a single sensor that takes parameters, but supplying only two of the four parameters that are used by the sensor.

Also supply a sensor filter that limits the column data that is shown to values that match the regex `.*Shared.*', and a sensor filter option that re-fetches any cached data that is older than 3600 seconds.

No question filters or question options supplied.

\paragraph{Ask manual human question sensor with filter and 2 options}

\paragraph{Ask manual question sensor complex}
\label{examples/ask_manual_question_sensor_complex:ask-manual-question-sensor-complex}\label{examples/ask_manual_question_sensor_complex::doc}
This provides an example for asking a manual question without using human strings.

It uses the Computer Name and Folder Name Search with RegEx Match sensors.

The second sensor has a single parameter, dirname, with a value of `Program Files'.

The second sensor also has 3 sensor filter options that set the max data age to 3600 seconds, does NOT ignore case, and treats all values as string.

There is also a question filter supplied that limits the rows that are displayed to computers that match an Operating System that contains Windows, and has 3 question filter options supplied that set the max data age to 3600 seconds, does NOT ignore case, and uses `and' to join all question filters.

Filters are used generously throughout pytan. When used as part of a

Options Help
============

Options are used for controlling how filters act. When options are
used as part of a sensor string, they change how the filters
supplied as part of that sensor operate. When options are used for
whole question options, they change how all of the question filters
operate.

When options are supplied for a sensor string, they must be
supplied as \PYGZsq{}, opt:OPTION\PYGZsq{} or \PYGZsq{}, opt:OPTION:VALUE\PYGZsq{} for options
that require a value.

When options are supplied for question options, they must be
supplied as \PYGZsq{}OPTION\PYGZsq{} or \PYGZsq{}OPTION:VALUE\PYGZsq{} for options that require

Options can be used on \PYGZsq{}filter\PYGZsq{} or \PYGZsq{}group\PYGZsq{}, where \PYGZsq{}group\PYGZsq{} pertains

Sensors Help
============

Supplying sensors controls what columns will be showed when you ask a
question.

A sensor string is a human string that describes, at a minimum, a sensor.
It can also optionally define a selector for the sensor, parameters for
the sensor, a filter for the sensor, and options for the filter for the
sensor. Sensors can be provided as a string or a list of strings.

Examples for basic sensors
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a single sensor:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name\PYGZsq{}

Supplying two sensors in a list of strings:

    [\PYGZsq{}Computer Name\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}IP Route Details\PYGZsq{}]

Supplying multiple sensors with selectors (name is the default
selector if none is supplied):

    [
        \PYGZsq{}Computer Name\PYGZsq{},
        \PYGZsq{}name:Computer Name\PYGZsq{},
        \PYGZsq{}id:1\PYGZsq{},
        \PYGZsq{}hash:123456789\PYGZsq{},
    ]

Sensor Parameters
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying parameters to a sensor can control the arguments that are
supplied to a sensor, if that sensor takes any arguments.

Sensor parameters must be surrounded with curly braces \PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{},
and must have a key and value specified that is separated by
an equals \PYGZsq{}=\PYGZsq{}. Multiple parameters must be seperated by
a comma \PYGZsq{},\PYGZsq{}. The key should match up to a valid parameter key
for the sensor in question.

If a parameter is supplied and the sensor doesn\PYGZsq{}t have a
corresponding key name, it will be ignored. If the sensor has
parameters and a parameter is NOT supplied then one of two
paths will be taken:

    * if the parameter does not require a default value, the
    parameter is left blank and not supplied.
    * if the parameter does require a value (pulldowns, for
    example), a default value is derived (for pulldowns,
    the first value available as a pulldown entry is used).

Examples for sensors with parameters
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a single sensor with a single parameter \PYGZsq{}dirname\PYGZsq{}:

    \PYGZsq{}Sensor With Params\PYGZob{}dirname=Program Files\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a single sensor with two parameters, \PYGZsq{}param1\PYGZsq{} and
\PYGZsq{}param2\PYGZsq{}:

    \PYGZsq{}Sensor With Params\PYGZob{}param1=value1,param2=value2\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{}

Sensor Filters
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a filter to a sensor controls what data will be shown in
those columns (sensors) you\PYGZsq{}ve provided.

Sensor filters can be supplied by adding \PYGZsq{}, that FILTER:VALUE\PYGZsq{},
where FILTER is a valid filter string, and VALUE is the string
that you want FILTER to match on.

See filter help for a list of all possible FILTER strings.

See options help for a list of options that can control how
the filter works.

Examples for sensors with filters
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a sensor with a filter that limits the results to only
show column data that matches the regular expression
\PYGZsq{}.*Windows.*\PYGZsq{} (Tanium does a case insensitive match by default):

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name, that contains:Windows\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a sensor with a filter that limits the results to only
show column data that matches the regular expression
\PYGZsq{}Microsoft.*\PYGZsq{}:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name, that starts with:Microsoft\PYGZsq{}

Supply a sensor with a filter that limits the results to only
show column data that has a version greater or equal to
\PYGZsq{}39.0.0.0\PYGZsq{}. Since this sensor uses Version as its default result
type, there is no need to change the value type using filter
options.

    \PYGZsq{}Installed Application Version\PYGZsq{} \PYGZbs{}
    \PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}Application Name=Google Chrome\PYGZcb{}, that =\PYGZgt{}:39.0.0.0\PYGZsq{}

Sensor Options
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying options to a sensor can change how the filter for
that sensor works.

Sensor options can be supplied by adding \PYGZsq{}, opt:OPTION\PYGZsq{} or
\PYGZsq{}, opt:OPTION:VALUE\PYGZsq{} for those options that require values,
where OPTION is a valid option string, and VALUE is the
appropriate value required by accordant OPTION.

See options help for a list of options that can control how
the filter works.

Examples for sensors with options
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a sensor with an option that forces tanium to
re\PYGZhy{}fetch any cached column data that is older than 1 minute:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name, opt:max\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}age:60\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a sensor with filter and an option that causes
Tanium to match case for the filter value:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name, that contains:Windows, opt:match\PYGZus{}case\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a sensor with a filter and an option that causes
Tanium to match all values supplied:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name, that contains:Windows, opt:match\PYGZus{}all\PYGZus{}values\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a sensor with a filter and a set of options that
causes Tanium to recognize the value type as String (which is
the default type for most sensors), re\PYGZhy{}fetch data older than
10 minutes, match any values, and match case:

    \PYGZsq{}Computer Name\PYGZsq{}, that contains:Windows, \PYGZsq{} \PYGZbs{}
    opt:value\PYGZus{}type:string, opt:max\PYGZus{}data\PYGZus{}age:600, \PYGZsq{} \PYGZbs{}
    \PYGZsq{}opt:match\PYGZus{}any\PYGZus{}value, opt:match\PYGZus{}case\PYGZsq{}
\end{Verbatim}

\paragraph{Deploy action with params against windows computers}
\label{examples/deploy_action_with_params_against_windows_computers:deploy-action-with-params-against-windows-computers}\label{examples/deploy_action_with_params_against_windows_computers::doc}
Deploy an action with parameters against only windows computers using human strings.

This will use the Package `Custom Tagging - Add Tags' and supply two parameters. The second parameter will be ignored because the package in question only requires one parameter.


\subparagraph{Example Python Code}

Package Help
============

Supplying package defines what package will be deployed as part of the
action.

A package string is a human string that describes, at a minimum, a
package. It can also optionally define a selector for the package,
and/or parameters for the package. A package must be provided as a string.

Examples for package
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying a package:

    \PYGZsq{}Distribute Tanium Standard Utilities\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a package by id:

    \PYGZsq{}id:1\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a package by hash:

    \PYGZsq{}hash:123456789\PYGZsq{}

Supplying a package by name:

    \PYGZsq{}name:Distribute Tanium Standard Utilities\PYGZsq{}

Package Parameters
\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}

Supplying parameters to a package can control the arguments
that are supplied to a package, if that package takes any arguments.

Package parameters must be surrounded with curly braces \PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{},
and must have a key and value specified that is separated by
an equals \PYGZsq{}=\PYGZsq{}. Multiple parameters must be seperated by
a comma \PYGZsq{},\PYGZsq{}. The key should match up to a valid parameter key
for the package in question.

If a parameter is supplied and the package doesn\PYGZsq{}t have a
corresponding key name, it will be ignored. If the package has
parameters and a parameter is NOT supplied then an exception
will be raised, printing out the JSON of the missing paramater
for the package in question.

Options Help
============

Options are used for controlling how filters act. When options are
used as part of a sensor string, they change how the filters
supplied as part of that sensor operate. When options are used for
whole question options, they change how all of the question filters

Filters are used generously throughout pytan. When used as part of a

\paragraph{Create action from json}
\label{examples/create_action_from_json:create-action-from-json}\label{examples/create_action_from_json::doc}
Export an action object to a JSON file, then create a new action object from the exported JSON file. Actions can not be deleted, so do not delete it. This will, in effect, `re-deploy' an action.

\paragraph{Create question from json}
\label{examples/create_question_from_json:create-question-from-json}\label{examples/create_question_from_json::doc}
Export a question object to a JSON file, then create a new question object from the exported JSON file. Questions can not be deleted, so do not delete it. This will, in effect, `re-ask' a question.

    \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{qtype}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{manual\PYGZus{}human}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

    \PYG{n}{out}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{..trimmed for brevity..}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n}{out} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{join}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{out}\PYG{p}{)}

\subsection{pytan.handler module}

The main {\hyperref[pytan:module-pytan]{\code{pytan}}} module that provides methods for programmatic use.


\subsubsection{Handler Class}
\label{pytan.handler:handler-class}\index{Handler (class in pytan.handler)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{pytan.handler.}\bfcode{Handler}}{\emph{username}, \emph{password}, \emph{host}, \emph{port=`444'}, \emph{loglevel=0}, \emph{debugformat=False}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Bases: \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/functions.html\#object}{\code{object}}

Creates a connection to a Tanium SOAP Server on host:port
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{username} : str
\begin{quote}

\emph{username} to connect to \emph{host} with
\end{quote}

\textbf{password} : str
\begin{quote}

\emph{password} to connect to \emph{host} with
\end{quote}

\textbf{host} : str
\begin{quote}

hostname or ip of Tanium SOAP Server
\end{quote}

\textbf{port} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

port of Tanium SOAP Server on \emph{host}
\end{quote}

\textbf{loglevel} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

0 should not print anything, 1 and higher will print more
\end{quote}

\textbf{debugformat} : bool, optional
\begin{quote}

False use one line logformat, True use two lines
\end{quote}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.LOG_LEVEL_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.LOG\_LEVEL\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
maps a given \emph{loglevel} to respective logger names and their logger levels

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.INFO_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.INFO\_FORMAT}}}}] \leavevmode
debugformat=False

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.DEBUG_FORMAT]{\code{pytan.constants.DEBUG\_FORMAT}}}}] \leavevmode
debugformat=True

\end{description}


\paragraph{Notes}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
port 444 is the default SOAP port

\item {} 
port 443 forwards /soap/ URLs to the SOAP port

\item {} 
Use port 444 if you have direct access to it

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\subparagraph{Asking a Manual Question}
\label{pytan.handler:asking-a-manual-question}\index{ask\_manual() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{ask\_manual}}{\emph{get\_results=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Ask a manual question using definitions and get the results back

This method requires in-depth knowledge of how filters and options are created in the API,
and as such is not meant for human consumption. Use {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual_human]{\code{ask\_manual\_human()}}} instead.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{sensor\_defs} : str, dict, list of str or dict
\begin{quote}

sensor definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_filter\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

question filter definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_option\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

question option definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after asking question

\item {} 
False: just ask the question and return it in \emph{ret}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ret} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{question\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.question.Question]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.question.Question}}}

\item {} 
\emph{question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.FILTER_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.FILTER\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid filter dictionaries for filters

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.OPTION\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid option dictionaries for options

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.ASK_KWARGS]{\code{pytan.constants.ASK\_KWARGS}}}}] \leavevmode
list of kwargs that can be passed to {\hyperref[taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker]{\code{taniumpy.question\_asker.QuestionAsker}}}

\end{description}

This method takes a string or list of strings and parses them into
their corresponding definitions needed by {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.ask_manual]{\code{ask\_manual()}}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{sensors} : str, list of str
\begin{quote}

sensors (columns) to include in question
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_filters} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

filters that apply to the whole question
\end{quote}

\textbf{question\_options} : str, list of str, optional
\begin{quote}

options that apply to the whole question
\end{quote}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after asking question

\item {} 
False: just ask the question and return it in result

\end{itemize}

\textbf{sensors\_help} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: do not print the help string for sensors

\item {} 
True: print the help string for sensors and exit

\end{itemize}

\textbf{filters\_help} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: do not print the help string for filters

\item {} 
True: print the help string for filters and exit

\end{itemize}

\textbf{options\_help} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: do not print the help string for options

\item {} 
True: print the help string for options and exit

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{result} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{question\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.question.Question]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.question.Question}}}

\item {} 
\emph{question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\subparagraph{Deploy an Action}
\label{pytan.handler:deploy-an-action}\index{deploy\_action() (pytan.handler.Handler method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{Handler.}\bfcode{deploy\_action}}{\emph{run=False}, \emph{get\_results=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Deploy an action and get the results back

This method requires in-depth knowledge of how filters and options are created in the API, and as such is not meant for human consumption. Use {\hyperref[pytan.handler:pytan.handler.Handler.deploy_action_human]{\code{deploy\_action\_human()}}} instead.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\textbf{package\_def} : dict
\begin{quote}

definition that describes a package
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_filter\_defs} : str, dict, list of str or dict, optional
\begin{quote}

action filter definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{action\_option\_defs} : dict, list of dict, optional
\begin{quote}

action filter option definitions
\end{quote}

\textbf{start\_seconds\_from\_now} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

start action N seconds from now
\end{quote}

\textbf{expire\_seconds} : int, optional
\begin{quote}

expire action N seconds from now, will be derived from package if not supplied
\end{quote}

\textbf{run} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
False: just ask the question that pertains to verify action, export the results to CSV, and raise RunFalse -- does not deploy the action

\item {} 
True: actually deploy the action

\end{itemize}

\textbf{get\_results} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
True: wait for result completion after deploying action

\item {} 
False: just deploy the action and return the object in \emph{ret}

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\textbf{ret} : dict, containing:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{action\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.action.Action]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.action.Action}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_human} : str, progress map in human form

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_map} : dict, progress map in dictionary form

\item {} 
\emph{pre\_action\_question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}


\strong{See also:}

\begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.FILTER_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.FILTER\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid filter dictionaries for filters

\item[{{\hyperref[pytan.constants:pytan.constants.OPTION_MAPS]{\code{pytan.constants.OPTION\_MAPS}}}}] \leavevmode
valid option dictionaries for options

\end{description}


\paragraph{Examples}

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} example of dict for {}`package\PYGZus{}def{}`}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{package\PYGZus{}def} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{name}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{PackageName1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{params}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{param1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{value1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} example of str for {}`action\PYGZus{}filter\PYGZus{}defs{}`}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{action\PYGZus{}filter\PYGZus{}defs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Sensor1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} example of dict for {}`action\PYGZus{}filter\PYGZus{}defs{}`}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{action\PYGZus{}filter\PYGZus{}defs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{name}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{Sensor1}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{filter}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{operator}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{RegexMatch}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{not\PYGZus{}flag}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{value}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{.*}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{options}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{and\PYGZus{}flag}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\textbf{options\_help} : bool, optional

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode

\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\emph{action\_object} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.action.Action]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.action.Action}}}

\emph{action\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\item {} 
\emph{action\_progress\_map} : dict, progress map in dictionary form

\item {} 
\emph{pre\_action\_question\_results} : {\hyperref[taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.result_set.ResultSet]{\code{taniumpy.object\_types.result\_set.ResultSet}}}

\begin{itemize}

\textbf{empty\_ok} : bool, optional
\begin{itemize}
\item {}

\end{itemize}

\subsection{pytan Functional Tests}
\label{pytan.functest:module-test_pytan_func}\label{pytan.functest::doc}\label{pytan.functest:pytan-functional-tests}\index{test\_pytan\_func (module)}
This contains functional tests for pytan.

These functional tests require a connection to a Tanium server in order to run.
The connection info is pulled from the SERVER\_INFO dictionary in test/API\_INFO.py.

These tests all use {\hyperref[ddt:module-ddt]{\code{ddt}}}, a package that provides for data driven tests via JSON files.

\subsection{taniumpy.question\_asker module}
\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy-question-asker-module}\label{taniumpy.question_asker:module-taniumpy.question_asker}\label{taniumpy.question_asker::doc}\index{taniumpy.question\_asker (module)}\index{QuestionAsker (class in taniumpy.question\_asker)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{taniumpy.question\_asker.}\bfcode{QuestionAsker}}{\emph{session}, \emph{question}, \emph{polling\_interval=None}, \emph{pct\_complete\_threshold=99}, \emph{timeout=300}}{}
Bases: \href{http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/functions.html\#object}{\code{object}}

A class to aid in asking a Question.

The primary function of this class is to poll for
result info for question, and fire off events:

ProgressChanged
AnswersChanged
AnswersComplete
\index{POLLING\_INTERVAL (taniumpy.question\_asker.QuestionAsker attribute)}

\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker.POLLING_INTERVAL}\pysigline{\bfcode{POLLING\_INTERVAL}\strong{ = 5}}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{run() (taniumpy.question\_asker.QuestionAsker method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.question_asker:taniumpy.question_asker.QuestionAsker.run}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{run}}{\emph{callbacks=\{\}}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Poll for question data and issue callbacks.

Callbacks should be a dict with members:
`ProgressChanged'
`AnswersChanged'
`AnswersComplete'

Each should be a function that accepts a QuestionAsker
and a percent complete.

Any callback can choose to get data from the session
by calling asker.session.getResultData(asker.question)

Polling will be stopped only when one of the callbacks
calls the stop() method or the answers are complete. Note
that callbacks can call setPercentCompleteThreshold to
change what done means on the fly

\end{fulllineitems}

\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType.from_jsonable}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{from\_jsonable}}{\emph{jsonable}}{}
Inverse of to\_jsonable, with explode\_json\_string\_values=False.

This can be used to import objects from serialized JSON. This JSON should come from BaseType.to\_jsonable(explode\_json\_string\_values=False, include+type=True)
\paragraph{Examples}

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{with} \PYG{n+nb}{open}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{question\PYGZus{}list.json}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n}{fd}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{n}{questions} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{json}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{loads}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fd}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{read}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} is a list of serialized questions}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{n}{question\PYGZus{}objects} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{BaseType}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{from\PYGZus{}jsonable}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{questions}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} will return a list of api.Question}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\phantomsection\label{taniumpy.object_types:taniumpy.object_types.base.BaseType.write_csv}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{write\_csv}}{\emph{fd}, \emph{val}, \emph{explode\_json\_string\_values=False}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Write `val' to CSV. val can be a BaseType instance or a list of
BaseType

This does a two-pass, calling to\_flat\_dict for each object, then
finding the union of all headers,
then writing out the value of each column for each object
sorted by header name

explode\_json\_string\_values attempts to see if any of the str values
are parseable by json.loads, and if so treat each property as a column
value

fd is a file-like object

\end{fulllineitems}

\phantomsection\label{xmltodict:xmltodict.parse}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{xmltodict.}\bfcode{parse}}{\emph{xml\_input}, \emph{encoding=None}, \emph{expat=\textless{}module `xml.parsers.expat' from `/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/\_xmlplus/parsers/expat.pyc'\textgreater{}}, \emph{process\_namespaces=False}, \emph{namespace\_separator=':'}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Parse the given XML input and convert it into a dictionary.

\emph{xml\_input} can either be a \emph{string} or a file-like object.

If \emph{xml\_attribs} is \emph{True}, element attributes are put in the dictionary
among regular child elements, using \emph{@} as a prefix to avoid collisions. If
set to \emph{False}, they are just ignored.

Simple example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{xmltodict}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a prop=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{x}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{@prop}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+go}{u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{doc}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{b}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+go}{[u\PYGZsq{}1\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}2\PYGZsq{}]}
\end{Verbatim}

If \emph{item\_depth} is \emph{0}, the function returns a dictionary for the root
element (default behavior). Otherwise, it calls \emph{item\_callback} every time
an item at the specified depth is found and returns \emph{None} in the end
(streaming mode).

The callback function receives two parameters: the \emph{path} from the document
root to the item (name-attribs pairs), and the \emph{item} (dict). If the
callback's return value is false-ish, parsing will be stopped with the
\code{ParsingInterrupted} exception.

Streaming example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{handle}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{print} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{path:}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s}{ item:}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZpc{}s}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{...}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a prop=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{x}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{  \PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item\PYGZus{}depth}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{item\PYGZus{}callback}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{path:[(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZob{}u\PYGZsq{}prop\PYGZsq{}: u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}\PYGZcb{}), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, None)] item:1}
\PYG{g+go}{path:[(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZob{}u\PYGZsq{}prop\PYGZsq{}: u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{}\PYGZcb{}), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, None)] item:2}
\end{Verbatim}

The optional argument \emph{postprocessor} is a function that takes \emph{path},
\emph{key} and \emph{value} as positional arguments and returns a new \emph{(key, value)}
pair where both \emph{key} and \emph{value} may have changed. Usage example:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{postprocessor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{try}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{key} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{:int}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{k}{except} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+ne}{ValueError}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+ne}{TypeError}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}1\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}2\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}b\PYGZgt{}x\PYGZlt{}/b\PYGZgt{}\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }                \PYG{n}{postprocessor}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{postprocessor}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}b:int\PYGZsq{}, [1, 2]), (u\PYGZsq{}b\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}x\PYGZsq{})]))])}
\end{Verbatim}

You can pass an alternate version of \emph{expat} (such as \emph{defusedexpat}) by
using the \emph{expat} parameter. E.g:

\begin{Verbatim}[frame=single,commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{defusedexpat}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{xmltodict}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZlt{}a\PYGZgt{}hello\PYGZlt{}/a\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{expat}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{defusedexpat}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pyexpat}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{OrderedDict([(u\PYGZsq{}a\PYGZsq{}, u\PYGZsq{}hello\PYGZsq{})])}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{unparse() (in module xmltodict)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{xmltodict:xmltodict.unparse}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{xmltodict.}\bfcode{unparse}}{\emph{input\_dict}, \emph{output=None}, \emph{encoding='utf-8'}, \emph{full\_document=True}, \emph{**kwargs}}{}
Emit an XML document for the given \emph{input\_dict} (reverse of \emph{parse}).

The resulting XML document is returned as a string, but if \emph{output} (a
file-like object) is specified, it is written there instead.

Dictionary keys prefixed with \emph{attr\_prefix} (default={}`'@'\emph{) are interpreted
as XML node attributes, whereas keys equal to {}`cdata\_key}
(default={}`'\#text'{}`) are treated as character data.

The \emph{pretty} parameter (default={}`False{}`) enables pretty-printing. In this
mode, lines are terminated with \emph{`n'} and indented with \emph{`t'}, but this
can be customized with the \emph{newl} and \emph{indent} parameters.

\end{fulllineitems}



\section{ddt module}
\label{ddt:module-ddt}\label{ddt::doc}\label{ddt:ddt-module}\index{ddt (module)}\index{data() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.data}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{data}}{\emph{*values}}{}
Method decorator to add to your test methods.

Should be added to methods of instances of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{ddt() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.ddt}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{ddt}}{\emph{cls}}{}
Class decorator for subclasses of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

Apply this decorator to the test case class, and then
decorate test methods with \code{@data}.

For each method decorated with \code{@data}, this will effectively create as
many methods as data items are passed as parameters to \code{@data}.

The names of the test methods follow the pattern
\code{original\_test\_name\_\{ordinal\}\_\{data\}}. \code{ordinal} is the position of the
data argument, starting with 1.

For data we use a string representation of the data value converted into a
valid python identifier.  If \code{data.\_\_name\_\_} exists, we use that instead.

For each method decorated with \code{@file\_data('test\_data.json')}, the
decorator will try to load the test\_data.json file located relative
to the python file containing the method that is decorated. It will,
for each \code{test\_name} key create as many methods in the list of values
from the \code{data} key.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{file\_data() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.file_data}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{file\_data}}{\emph{value}}{}
Method decorator to add to your test methods.

Should be added to methods of instances of \code{unittest.TestCase}.

\code{value} should be a path relative to the directory of the file
containing the decorated \code{unittest.TestCase}. The file
should contain JSON encoded data, that can either be a list or a
dict.

In case of a list, each value in the list will correspond to one
test case, and the value will be concatenated to the test method
name.

In case of a dict, keys will be used as suffixes to the name of the
test case, and values will be fed as test data.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{is\_hash\_randomized() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.is_hash_randomized}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{is\_hash\_randomized}}{}{}
\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mk\_test\_name() (in module ddt)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{ddt:ddt.mk_test_name}\pysiglinewithargsret{\code{ddt.}\bfcode{mk\_test\_name}}{\emph{name}, \emph{value}, \emph{index=0}}{}
Generate a new name for a test case.

It will take the original test name and append an ordinal index and a
string representation of the value, and convert the result into a valid
python identifier by replacing extraneous characters with \code{\_}.

If hash randomization is enabled (a feature available since 2.7.3/3.2.3
and enabled by default since 3.3) and a ``non-trivial'' value is passed
this will omit the name argument by default. Set \emph{PYTHONHASHSEED}
to a fixed value before running tests in these cases to get the
names back consistently or use the \emph{\_\_name\_\_} attribute on data values.

A ``trivial'' value is a plain scalar, or a tuple or list consisting
only of trivial values.

\end{fulllineitems}
